ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Writing and analytical skills

Great introduction to the historiography of memory and testimony! Class discussions of the rhetorical use of testimony in secondary sources was a new way to develop writing skills. The readings all tied together very well-it's clear Prof. Dean put a lot of time into thinking about the most valuable sources and excerpts for us to read in conjunction.
Better understanding of Holocaust history and historiography; essay writing skills; seminar-level discussion techniques
How to think critically about the ways testimony has been used to remember the Holoucast.
I gained an understanding of the field of Holocaust testimony and considered a number of challenges related to telling stories about the Holocaust and Holocaust survivorship.

This course taught me how to think critically about historical testimony and gave me the correct tools to evaluate how history and historical writing has engaged with the Holocaust. Each class session was thought provoking and its format as a seminar gave far more insight than a lecture could. We read a wide array of books and placed primary and secondary sources in conversation with each other.

I learned a lot about how historical memory can be affected by the inclusion of testimony. We studied in great detail the kinds of testimonies, sources, and narratives we can look to to gain a holistic understanding of the Holocaust on a more personal level, rather than just facts.
A deeper understanding of not only the Holocaust but also survivor testimonies; exploration of how memory works

I learned so much about the history of memory and different historiographical approaches to understanding events like the Holocaust. I really loved this course and the readings are worthwhile if you take the time to engage with them!
So much more than a basic level of knowledge about the Holocaust.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Dean is extremely intelligent and synthesized our points in an effective discussion. She posed very thoughtful questions and was extremely vital in our class discussions to push us further.

Weakness: More feedback on writing would be great

Strengths: Readings, class discussion, excellent look at "how to write history."

Weaknesses: The writing expectations required a lot of independent motivation and contemplation-I enjoyed that exercise but I know some found it stressful.

Strengths: interesting reading, good discussion
Improvements: some more detailed feedback on essays would have been helpful; having the essay for a book due the same week that we have to read the book gets a little but crunched for time
Maybe a little more structure for each session would help, but the discussion based classes are also quite interesting.

I have no ways to improve this class other than asking the professor perhaps set requirements earlier in the semester for the final paper (Eg, having a rough draft due or a bibliography). That being said, it is a junior level seminar for history majors and students should know how to manage their time.

The style of the seminar is very, very discussion-based. It's like a 2 hour long conversation, which has its merits. In order to get the most out of the class, it is important to come prepared having done the readings (which are enjoyable and interesting) and feed into the conversation. This isn't difficult because the conversations take place after a student presents some guiding questions. This is the kind of class where you don't even really take notes, you just engage in conversation -- and the conversations are interesting and thought-provoking enough that you can retain the information.
Strength: very interesting content, good organization, good readings

This course was great overall -- discussion was really productive in general and Prof Dean is a wonderful, thoughtful discussion leader. At times, discussion could get tiring but that is sort of the nature of the course given that it's a longer seminar and each session focuses on a single book.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Very intellectually interesting and pushed me as a student

Yes! The ideas about writing and synthesis we talked about in class found their way into my writing for other courses-I felt like the themes of this course lined up perfectly with my greater academic interests in very surprising ways! You do not have to know anything about the Holocaust or even be particularly interested in it as a subject to get a lot of value out of this course.

I would, especially for people interested in this specific subject. You have to read at least a book a week, but the themes and subjects are engaging. The essays are very self-directed, and Prof. Dean is pleasant/easy to talk to
Yes! its a great class that inspires a lot of self reflection too.

Yes! For anyone who wants to understand the Holocaust and the values we place on its history, taking this class is a great first step. The books were hard emotionally, but each one was an important and beyond worthwhile read.

Absolutely. Prof Dean is wonderful and somewhat laidback. This helps create a class environment where everyone can feel comfortable sharing without fear of a right or wrong answer. If you have any interest at all in memory/history, the Holocaust, or working with source material that isn't pure textbook information, this is a great class to take. The workload is more than manageable.
Yes! Prof. Dean was great at facilitating discussion, and the course was well-organized with very interesting readings that explored different aspects of the Holocaust experience
Yes, absolutely! This is a laidback seminar where you learn a ton! Professor Dean is a wonderful discussion leader and a lovely person. Definitely take this course!
Yes I loved learning everything this course had to offer
